questions.text: How is the PQLI score calculated?
questions.solution:
• PQLI (Physical Quality of Life Index) is a measure focusing on quality of life outcomes rather than economic input indicators.
  • Indicators Used: It combines three social indicators:
    • Literacy Rate: Reflects educational access and literacy within the population.
    • Infant Mortality Rate: Indicates healthcare quality, especially in maternal and child health.
    • Life Expectancy at Age One: Represents the general health and longevity of a population.
  • Scoring System: Each indicator is standardized on a scale from 0 (worst) to 100 (best), allowing cross-country and temporal comparisons.
  • Calculation Method: By averaging these scores, PQLI emphasizes outcome-based measurements of wellbeing, providing a holistic view of societal health beyond economic data alone.

Why Not Others:

  • A: GDP, though an economic measure, does not assess physical quality of life directly.
  • C: The PQLI takes an average rather than selecting the highest score, ensuring balanced representation.
  • D: Simply subtracting infant mortality from life expectancy omits literacy and doesn't capture the full quality of life.

Key Takeaways: PQLI is an outcome-focused, composite index designed for easy comparison of quality of life across countries, based on three core health and education metrics.

questions.text: Which organization is responsible for the creation and implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)?
questions.solution:
• The 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development by the UN was built upon the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs), expanding the focus to include social, economic, and environmental sustainability.
  • Global Participation: Over 190 countries adopted the SDGs, making them a universal framework applicable to both developed and developing nations.
  • Comprehensive Scope: The 17 SDGs cover diverse areas like poverty eradication, climate action, quality education, and reduced inequalities, with health as an integral part (Goal 3).
  • Implementation: The UN collaborates with governments, civil society, and the private sector to guide and monitor progress toward achieving these goals by 2030.

Why Not Others:

  • A (WHO): Plays a major role in health-related targets within SDG 3 but does not govern the entire SDG framework.
  • C (IMF): Focuses on economic stability and financial policies, not broad social development.
  • D (World Bank): Provides financial and technical support for development but isn't the primary driver of the SDG agenda.

Key Takeaways:

The UN-led SDGs represent a globally coordinated effort to tackle critical issues by 2030, emphasizing sustainability, equality, and health, with 17 goals and 169 targets involving multi-sector collaboration.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the calculation of YLD in DALYs?
questions.solution:
• Disability-Adjusted Life Year (DALY) is a comprehensive metric used to assess the overall burden of disease, combining the effects of both premature death and disability.
  • DALY=YLD+YLL.
  • YLD (Years Lived with Disability) captures the impact of non-fatal conditions, accounting for incidence (new cases), duration of disability, and severity.
  • Severity Weighting: Each condition has a weight from 0 to 1, where 0 is perfect health and 1 is equivalent to death, allowing a standardized comparison across different diseases.
  • YLL (Years of Life Lost) is another DALY component, calculated by multiplying deaths at each age by the remaining expected years of life based on a standard life expectancy, often modelled on Japanese life expectancy.
  • Application: DALY is widely used in public health planning, resource allocation, and health impact assessment to identify high-burden diseases and prioritize interventions.
  • Social Weighting: In some models, a social weighting system gives higher value to years lost during young adulthood, reflecting societal preferences for productivity.

Why Not Others:

  • B: YLD reflects not only the number of cases but also the duration and severity of the condition.
  • C: Severity alone is not sufficient; YLD includes incidence and duration.
  • D: Chronic conditions are integral to DALY calculations due to their long-term impact on health.

Key Takeaways:

YLD in DALYs accounts for both incidence and duration of disability, with a severity weighting, making it an essential measure for assessing the impact of both fatal and non-fatal conditions on public health.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT one of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)?
questions.solution:
• Historical Context of SDGs: The SDGs followed the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs), expanding on them with broader and more ambitious goals covering social, economic, and environmental dimensions.
  • Structure and Targets: The SDGs comprise 17 goals and 169 specific targets, addressing issues such as inequality, environmental sustainability, economic growth, and global partnerships.
  • SDG 3 and Universal Health: While Universal Health Coverage (UHC) is part of SDG 3 (Good Health and Well-being), it is not its own SDG. UHC aims to ensure that everyone has access to essential health services without financial hardship, but it remains a target rather than a standalone goal.
  • Global Collaboration: The success of SDGs relies on global partnerships (SDG 17), engaging governments, private sectors, and civil societies in all countries to address these goals collectively.

Why Not Others:

  • A (No Poverty): SDG 1 is centred on eradicating poverty globally in all forms, a fundamental goal for sustainable development.
  • B (Zero Hunger): SDG 2 aims to achieve food security and improved nutrition through sustainable agriculture.
  • D (Climate Action): SDG 13 stresses the need for climate change action to minimize its impacts on societies and ecosystems.

Key Takeaways: "Universal Healthcare" is a target under SDG 3 but not an SDG by itself. The SDGs provide a comprehensive framework for addressing diverse challenges worldwide, from poverty and hunger to environmental conservation, to achieve a sustainable and inclusive future by 2030.

questions.text: When were the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) adopted?
questions.solution:
• Sustainable Development Vision: The SDGs aim to end poverty, protect the planet, and ensure prosperity for all, reflecting a commitment to inclusive and sustainable development.
  • Global Participation: The SDGs were developed through an extensive consultative process involving governments, civil society, private sector, and the general public, ensuring a comprehensive approach to global challenges.
  • Universal Goals: Unlike the MDGs, which primarily focused on developing countries, the SDGs are designed to be universal, applying to all nations, regardless of their level of development.
  • Monitoring and Review: The implementation of the SDGs is monitored through a robust follow-up and review mechanism, involving national reporting, global reviews, and the participation of stakeholders to ensure accountability and progress.
  • Integration with National Policies: Countries are encouraged to integrate the SDGs into their national development plans and strategies, aligning them with national priorities and specific contexts.
  • Funding and Investment: Achieving the SDGs requires significant financial investment, prompting discussions around financing mechanisms, public-private partnerships, and innovative funding solutions to mobilize the necessary resources.
  • COVID-19 Impact: The COVID-19 pandemic significantly affected progress towards the SDGs, highlighting the need for resilient systems and greater emphasis on health and social protection.

Why Not Others:

  • A (2013): The discussions began earlier, but the formal adoption happened in 2015.
  • B (2019): The SDGs were already in place by 2019; efforts were focused on their implementation.
  • D (2020): This year was part of the decade for action, not the adoption date.

Key Takeaways: The Sustainable Development Goals, adopted in 2015, represent a universal agenda aimed at transforming our world through inclusive development, with a focus on partnerships, financing, and accountability to ensure no one is left behind.

questions.text: Who developed the Physical Quality of Life Index?
questions.solution:
• Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI): Developed by Morris David Morris in the 1970s, the PQLI is a composite index that offers a more comprehensive measure of quality of life compared to traditional economic indicators like GDP.
  • Components of PQLI:
    • Infant Mortality Rate (IMR): A crucial health indicator reflecting the health status of a population; lower rates suggest better healthcare and living conditions.
    • Life Expectancy at Age One: This measure indicates the overall health of a population and the effectiveness of health systems; higher life expectancy correlates with improved quality of life.
    • Literacy Rate: An essential indicator of education, literacy impacts economic opportunities, social mobility, and overall societal development.
  • Methodology:
    • Each of the three components is scaled from 0 to 100 based on performance relative to the best and worst countries, and the PQLI is calculated as the average of these scaled scores, providing a clearer picture of quality of life.
  • Significance of PQLI:
    • Focus on Health and Education: The PQLI emphasizes the importance of health and education as critical components of human development, shifting the focus from purely economic measures to a broader understanding of well-being.
    • Influence on Policy: By incorporating non-economic indicators, the PQLI has encouraged policymakers to adopt holistic approaches to development, fostering investments in health and education.
    • Comparative Tool: The index serves as a valuable tool for comparing quality of life across countries and over time, aiding in identifying trends and informing policy decisions.
  • Legacy and Impact:
    • Morris's work laid the foundation for subsequent measures of human development, such as the Human Development Index (HDI), which incorporates life expectancy, education, and income.
    • His contributions have influenced various fields, including economics, public health, and education, reinforcing the importance of multi-dimensional approaches to assessing human well-being.

Why Not Others:

  • A (World Bank): The World Bank focuses on economic development and poverty reduction, not specifically the PQLI.
  • B (Raunald Ross): Raunald Ross is not recognized for developing indices related to quality of life.
  • D (World Health Organization): While the WHO addresses health-related metrics, it did not create the PQLI.

Key Takeaways: The Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI), developed by Morris David Morris, is a significant measure that integrates health, education, and social factors, providing a more comprehensive assessment of quality of life beyond traditional economic indicators.

questions.text: How is Years of Life Lost (YLL) calculated in the context of DALYs
questions.solution:
• Years of Life Lost (YLL): This metric quantifies the years lost due to premature death and is a critical component of the Disability-Adjusted Life Year (DALY) framework, which assesses the overall disease burden in a population.
  • Calculation of YLL:
    • Formula: YLL = Number of deaths × Standard life expectancy at the age of death.
    • This approach captures the potential years lost for each individual who dies prematurely, reflecting the impact of mortality on public health.
  • Context of DALYs:
    • Disability-Adjusted Life Year (DALY) is a composite measure that combines two key elements:
      • Years of Life Lost (YLL): Represents the years lost due to premature mortality.
      • Years Lost to Disability (YLD): Reflects the years lived with disability due to health conditions. Calculated by multiplying the number of incident cases of disease by the average duration and applying a severity weight.
    • DALY Formula: DALY = YLL + YLD. This formula allows for a comprehensive understanding of both mortality and morbidity within a population.
  • Purpose and Application:
    • DALYs provide insight into the burden of disease and health conditions, facilitating comparisons between different health issues and populations.
    • The concept originated from research by Harvard University for the World Bank in 1990 and was adopted by the World Health Organization (WHO) in 2000, enhancing its global application in public health assessments.
  • Standard Life Expectancy:
    • The Japanese life expectancy statistics are often used as a benchmark, given Japan's high life expectancy, providing a standard for measuring premature death and YLL across populations.
  • Social Weighting:
    • DALY calculations incorporate social weighting, which assigns different values to years of life lost based on age. This reflects societal preferences for productivity, often valuing years lived as a young adult more highly than those spent in childhood or old age.

Why Not Others:

  • B (Number of deaths multiplied by the average age of the population): This does not account for standard life expectancy and misrepresents the concept of YLL.
  • C (Number of deaths divided by the standard life expectancy at the age of death): Incorrectly applies division, rather than multiplication, in calculating YLL.
  • D (Number of deaths divided by the average age of the population): Fails to represent the relationship between deaths and standard life expectancy, leading to inaccurate YLL calculation.

Key Takeaways: Years of Life Lost (YLL) is calculated by multiplying the number of deaths by the standard life expectancy at the age of death, providing critical insight into the impact of premature mortality on public health. The concept is a core component of DALYs, which combines both premature death and disability to assess overall health burden.

questions.text: The Declaration of Alma-Ata calls for urgent and effective national and international action to develop and implement what?
questions.solution:
• Declaration of Alma-Ata: Adopted in 1978 during the International Conference on Primary Health Care in Alma-Ata (now Almaty, Kazakhstan), this declaration emphasized the importance of primary health care (PHC) as a cornerstone for achieving health for all.
  • Focus on Primary Health Care (PHC):
    • The declaration asserts that PHC is essential for promoting health equity and addressing the basic health needs of populations.
    • It calls for a comprehensive approach to health that goes beyond specialized medical services, emphasizing the need for accessible, affordable, and community-based health services.
  • Key Components of Primary Health Care:
    • Education about prevailing health problems and prevention methods.
    • Promotion of food supply and proper nutrition to improve health outcomes.
    • Access to safe water and basic sanitation to prevent diseases.
    • Maternal and child health care, including family planning, to enhance reproductive health.
    • Immunization against infectious diseases to protect vulnerable populations.
    • Prevention and control of endemic diseases to reduce disease burden.
    • Appropriate treatment of common diseases and injuries to ensure timely care.
    • Provision of essential drugs to facilitate treatment and improve health access.

Why Not Others:

  • A (Specialized medical services): The declaration emphasizes comprehensive primary care rather than specialized services.
  • C (Universal health insurance): While important, the declaration specifically advocates for primary health care as a strategy for health system strengthening, not exclusively insurance.
  • D (Private hospital networks): The focus is on community-based and public health initiatives rather than privatization of healthcare services.

Key Takeaways: The Declaration of Alma-Ata emphasizes the urgent need for Primary Health Care (PHC) to promote health equity and address basic health needs. Key components of PHC include health education, nutrition promotion, sanitation, maternal and child health, immunization, disease prevention, treatment of common illnesses, and access to essential drugs.

questions.text: How is the Education Index in the HDI calculated?
questions.solution:
• Education Index in the Human Development Index (HDI):
    • The Education Index is a crucial component of the HDI, measuring the ability to acquire knowledge.
    • It is calculated by combining two key components:
      • Mean Years of Schooling: The average number of years of education received by people aged 25 and older.
      • Expected Years of Schooling: The total number of years of schooling that a child can expect to receive if current enrollment ratios persist throughout their life.
    • Components of HDI:
      • The HDI assesses three fundamental dimensions of human development:
        • Health: Measured by life expectancy at birth, reflecting the health and longevity of the population.
        • Education: Captured through the Education Index, as explained above.
        • Standard of Living: Measured by gross national income (GNI) per capita, adjusted for purchasing power parity (PPP).
      • Significance of HDI:
        • The HDI provides a more comprehensive understanding of human development beyond just income.
        • It reflects achievements in basic human capabilities: living a long life, being knowledgeable, and achieving a decent standard of living.
        • The index ranges from 0 to 1, with a higher value indicating better development. It helps assess a country's progress and allows for international comparisons.

Why Not Others:

  • A (Average number of years of schooling received by people aged 25 and older): While this contributes to the Education Index, it does not encompass the expected years of schooling.
  • B (Expected years of schooling for children entering school): This measure alone does not include the mean years of schooling for adults, which is a critical part of the index.
  • D (Literacy rate of the adult population): Literacy is important, but it is not directly used in calculating the Education Index.

Key Takeaways: The Education Index in the Human Development Index (HDI) is calculated by combining the mean years of schooling for adults and the expected years of schooling for children.

questions.text: The Jakarta Declaration on Health Promotion recognizes which factor as essential for sustainable health promotion?
questions.solution:
• Jakarta Declaration on Health Promotion:
    • Adopted during the Fourth International Conference on Health Promotion in July 1997, held in Jakarta, Indonesia.
    • It set a vision for health promotion into the 21st century, emphasizing the need to address health determinants comprehensively.
  • Key Aspects of the Declaration:
    • It highlights essential factors for sustainable health promotion, including:
      • Peace: A stable and peaceful environment is crucial for promoting health.
      • Shelter and Education: Access to adequate housing and education plays a significant role in health outcomes.
      • Social Security and Relations: These provide support and foster community bonds.
      • Food and Income: Essential for meeting basic needs and promoting well-being.
      • Women's Empowerment: Recognizing the role of women in health promotion and their rights is vital.
      • Ecosystem Stability and Resource Use: Sustainable practices ensure long-term health benefits.
      • Social Justice and Human Rights: Addressing inequalities enhances health promotion efforts.
      • Equity: Ensuring equal access to health resources and opportunities.
  • Focus on Community-Based Approaches:
    • The Jakarta Declaration emphasizes the importance of community-based approaches in health promotion.
    • Engaging communities in identifying their health needs and solutions fosters ownership and sustainability.
    • Community involvement is key to addressing the social determinants of health and achieving equity.

Why Not Others:

  • A (Technological advancements): While technology can support health promotion, it is not deemed essential as a standalone factor.
  • B (Corporate social responsibility): Important, but it is not highlighted as a fundamental factor in the Jakarta Declaration.
  • D (Isolation of health promotion efforts): Contradicts the principles of the declaration, which advocates for integrated and inclusive approaches.

Key Takeaways: The Jakarta Declaration emphasizes community-based approaches as essential for sustainable health promotion, recognizing that health determinants such as peace, education, and social equity play critical roles.

questions.text: Which organization is responsible for publishing the HDI?
questions.solution:
• Human Development Index (HDI):
    • Developed by the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) in 1990 as a measure of human development.
    • Provides a composite index that focuses on three key dimensions:
      • Health: Measured by life expectancy at birth.
      • Education: Assessed through mean years of schooling and expected years of schooling.
      • Standard of Living: Measured by gross national income (GNI) per capita adjusted for purchasing power parity (PPP).
  • UNDP's Role:
    • The UNDP publishes the Human Development Report annually, which includes HDI rankings and assessments.
    • The report aims to promote policies that improve the quality of life and human well-being beyond just economic growth.
  • Disparities in HDI:
    • The HDI highlights regional disparities in human development, illustrating that economic prosperity does not always correlate with HDI values.
    • Two countries with similar income per capita can exhibit different HDI scores due to variations in health and education outcomes.
    • This indicates that income alone is not a comprehensive measure of human development; other factors must be considered.

Why Not Others:

  • A (World Bank): While influential in economic data, it does not publish the HDI.
  • B (International Monetary Fund - IMF): Focuses on macroeconomic stability and financial stability rather than human development indices.
  • D (World Health Organization - WHO): Primarily concerned with global health issues and does not publish the HDI.

Key Takeaways: The United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) is responsible for publishing the Human Development Index (HDI), which assesses countries based on health, education, and income.
